Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2009 06:01PM MelMcG wrote: I might be a little late to this discussion but it sounds like I am in good company.  I've been looking everywhere to find information on radial scars and how recommended it is to do a needle localization biopsy (i.e. basically remove the radial scar).  Info is hard to find.  I went for my first mammo in May because I hit 40, not because I found or felt anything.  So this is all my baseline, but they called me back because my mammo was "abnormal."  I had three more sets of mammos that even involved twisting!  From there they recommended an ultrasound (which was inconclusive) and from there they recommended an MRI - which showed four different suspicious areas.  They only felt the need to biopsy two of the areas with an MRI guided needle biopsy.  One of the areas came out as a benign adenosis and the other a benign radial scar.  The breast specialist wanted to talk to the pathologist and radiologist further about my radial scar.  I had the follow up appointment today and the specialist "strongly recommends" the additional biopsy.  Apparently 1-2% of biopsies are radial scars, and of that, 10-20% of radial scars are malignant.  I have no family history (one cousin of about 70!)  My thought is that it is better to be safe than sorry and just have them take it out.  They tell me that my size is an advantage (34GG) and the excision may not even be noticeable.  I'm not as worried about the notice as I am about going through a possible unncessary medical procedure.  I have two dear friends sick with uterine and ovarian cancers so I am leaning towards doing the biopsy.  I'm just worried about complications from the procedure.  Does anyone have any thoughts?

Posts.Content: Aug 12, 2009 03:52PM MelMcG wrote: Thank you so much for this very helpful information and opinion.  The official name for my radial scar is a "radial scar with usual ductal hyperplasia and associated microcalcifications." I'm not sure if I have any atypia.  I'm still learning what all of this means. I'm not sure how many cores were removed, but I do know they used an 8 gauge needle.  I also have very dense, fibrocystic breasts and the mammo showed a swelling on the right side (although they have nothing to compare it to since my baseline mammo was in May and the subsequent sets were only a couple weeks later and I don't believe there was additional swelling between those). Juliecc, I hope your pre-op went well.  I'd love to hear how your surgery goes - it sounds very similar to what is planned for me - wire plus excision.  Doc told me mine would be sedation not general, outpatient, and should only take about an hour.  My radial scar is very, very deep (the first biopsy caused a HUGE hematoma on the inner side of my breast even though they went in from the outside.  They biopsied two sites at the same time so I'm sure that didn't help.  They still may be able to do this one along my arreola as well.  I haven't scheduled yet but reading through these comments I am definitely leaning towards it.
